Well, I think you get the use case. Read-only access to a set of input data and write access to working and output data, plus an application container that can be used on different sets of data. This would avoid building a full container every time. Instead, just the input data would be pulled into an empty image, or one with some minimal data wrangling tools. This could be thrown away later if the references to the data are kept.

OK, since my last question was so successful, here’s another one: what about data containers? That is, building a container to hold data, either readonly or read-write, and mounting it inside another container? This allows the reuse of applications to work on different datasets. Also, the input data can be kept static, while the working and output data can be collected.

Hey, <@U247AF8DP>, yes, we’ll run a separate and persistent JupyterHub server, so just the kernels will run on the HPC cluster. The kernels will run as a batch job and dialing in the wallclock will be part of the challenge. Lower wallclock requests tend to give faster scheduling, but also limit the length of time to be used. So, TBD on what’s best. Saving state between jobs or sessions would be something for a second round. First we want to sort out data handling and how fancy to get with containers (e.g., user managed containers for their kernels?).

attachments.title: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release Sep 15, 2017 / Release 2.3.2 This dot release includes a fix for a change that Docker implemented to their registry RESTful API which broke compatibility with Singularity (among several other low minor fixes).What happened?Where does Docker image metadata come from?The Docker Registry serves metadata about images via manifests, where each image has a manifest that tells Singularity important information like environment, labels, and entrypoints and running command. Importantly, the image manifest serves the actual layers that should be obtained to create the image. The manifests come in different flavors, or schema versions. Version 1 serves the primary load of metadata (labels, environment) while the first release of version 2 served layers, and had the addition of size. This addition made it possible to pull an image with Singularity and calculate the size on the fly for images generated with support for this manifest.Singularity had an old default to retrieve the version 2 (done by way of a header asking for it), and ask it for layers. If the remote registry could only offer version 1, we were still able to obtain a list of layers (under a different key, fsLayers instead of layers) and metadata via the older (schema 1) manifest. However, with the update, the API version 2 schema can now return a list of manifests. This meant that when we checked the response for the keys layers or fslayers, they wouldn’t be found, becaues we needed to look under manifests, and then do a second call to retrieve the manifest of interest based on a system architecture and OS. This of course broke most import, shell, pull, exec, because all of these commands require retrieving the layers.The PatchA super quick fix would have been to fall back to the version 1 manifest, always, but then we would lose the automatic calculation of size, which is important to many users. The “better” fix is obvious - the code needs to: check for a manifests key if found, select a default manifest to use retrieve it, and continue! if not found, fall back to version 1This means that we’ve added environment variables SINGULARITY_DOCKER_OS and SINGULARITY_DOCKER_ARCHITECTURE to specify this choice, with defaults linux and amd64. This is a pretty exciting change, because it means down the line you (as a user!) can specify the specifics of the layers you want returned, given an image that has this metadata available. We can see the fix running as follows:DEBUG *** STARTING DOCKER IMPORT PYTHON ****This is the initialization of the Docker client, it’s parsing the image name providedDEBUG Starting Docker IMPORT, includes env, runscript, and metadata.VERBOSE Docker image: ubuntu:14.04VERBOSE2 Specified Docker ENTRYPOINT as %runscript.DEBUG Headers found: Content-Type,AcceptVERBOSE Registry: index.docker.ioVERBOSE Namespace: libraryVERBOSE Repo Name: ubuntuVERBOSE Repo Tag: 14.04VERBOSE Version: NoneThe initial poke to Docker hub asks for tags, to determine if we need some kind of tokenVERBOSE Obtaining tags: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/listDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/list401> means that we do, and with the response the API sends back the scope and other details we need to make to request itDEBUG Http Error with code 401Here we are requesting itDEBUG GET <https://auth.docker.io/token?service=registry.docker.io&expires_in=9000&scope=repository:library/ubuntu:pullDEBUG> Headers found: Content-Type,Authorization,AcceptAnd here is the new bit. Instead of blindly doing one call, we have a function to update two versions of the manifest - the older (with metadata) and some version of the newer (with layers and size) with a fallback to use the version 1DEBUG Updating manifests.# Here is version 2+DEBUG MANIFEST (Primary): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latest#> Here is version 1 (Metadata)DEBUG MANIFEST (Metadata): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestNotice> that the two calls are the same - that’s because the headers are actually different, to request different ones.And here is the (new) indication that we found a listDEBUG Image manifest version 2.2 list found.Here is the default architecture / osDEBUG Obtaining architecture: amd64, OS: linuxAnd the specific call to get itVERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afWith> this fix - we can again use pull/import, etc, and also have a working singularity pull <docker://busybox> that estimates the size automatically.Please report any additional bugs to our issues board. Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Sep 27, 2017

Hi <@U2H1DRV52>.  <@U115P26TB> can add or detract from my response, but I think I can give you a pretty good answer.  
Singularity doesn’t use layers because they introduce some problems for reproducibility and having a single image file allows you to do some neat stuff that would otherwise be impossible.  
But, if your build fails and you don’t want to start all over again you still have some options.  
For instance you can rebuild into your image or directory without going through the bootstrap steps in the header.  This is the default behavior in 2.4 if you build into an existing writable image or directory.
You can also use the `--section` option to build just a single section.

<@U5Z4CFJS0> No. The reason why non-root build from shub has stopped working in 2.4 is because the images hosted on shub right now are of the ext3 format. Build attempts to download the image, and then re-build the ext3 image into the new squashfs format instead of how pull simply downloads the image full. Pulling from shub will remain as a legacy form of downloading the older image format directly without converting to squashfs. Using build on a shub image that has been built as a squashfs image using 2.4 (once 2.4 is released, shub should soon after gain this ability) will work without root, as we won’t need to convert to a new image type.

attachments.title: Standard Container Integration Format (SCI-F) Final Draft | Singularity
attachments.text: Standard Container Integration Format (SCI-F) Final Draft Sep 26, 2017 / Hi Singularity Community!Thanks to everyone that provided comments on the early draft for SCI-F. The goals were initially: write specification draft (this was done via a Google Doc) implement into Singularity (now in development branch) get feedback on both, adjust implementation and draft do several (N=4) implemented use cases for SCI-F, write up (available here) make an interactive, open source repository to contribute and share SCI-F apps <http://containers-ftw.org/apps/> write up the (almost) “final” draft formally <http://containers-ftw.org/SCI-F/I’m> (@vsoch) happy to report that I’ve finished the above, and I’d like to ask the following: if you contributed, please check the AUTHORS file in the SCI-F repository to make sure that I added you, and spelled your name correctly (apologies in advance). Any further suggestions, additions, or entire new contributions can be added to the draft by way of pull request. I’m not in any rush, and if you have a good contribution, I want to help. If you have not contributed yet and would like to, see the ideas linked on the draft abstract page.The plan is (as of now) to submit this no later than the end of October, and I want to make sure everyone that wants to contribute has had ample chance. Indeed, with Singularity there are many ways to cook your container, and SCi-F definitely exemplifies that.Thanks again everyone! Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Sep 27, 2017

attachments.title: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release Sep 15, 2017 / Release 2.3.2 This dot release includes a fix for a change that Docker implemented to their registry RESTful API which broke compatibility with Singularity (among several other low minor fixes).What happened?Where does Docker image metadata come from?The Docker Registry serves metadata about images via manifests, where each image has a manifest that tells Singularity important information like environment, labels, and entrypoints and running command. Importantly, the image manifest serves the actual layers that should be obtained to create the image. The manifests come in different flavors, or schema versions. Version 1 serves the primary load of metadata (labels, environment) while the first release of version 2 served layers, and had the addition of size. This addition made it possible to pull an image with Singularity and calculate the size on the fly for images generated with support for this manifest.Singularity had an old default to retrieve the version 2 (done by way of a header asking for it), and ask it for layers. If the remote registry could only offer version 1, we were still able to obtain a list of layers (under a different key, fsLayers instead of layers) and metadata via the older (schema 1) manifest. However, with the update, the API version 2 schema can now return a list of manifests. This meant that when we checked the response for the keys layers or fslayers, they wouldn’t be found, becaues we needed to look under manifests, and then do a second call to retrieve the manifest of interest based on a system architecture and OS. This of course broke most import, shell, pull, exec, because all of these commands require retrieving the layers.The PatchA super quick fix would have been to fall back to the version 1 manifest, always, but then we would lose the automatic calculation of size, which is important to many users. The “better” fix is obvious - the code needs to: check for a manifests key if found, select a default manifest to use retrieve it, and continue! if not found, fall back to version 1This means that we’ve added environment variables SINGULARITY_DOCKER_OS and SINGULARITY_DOCKER_ARCHITECTURE to specify this choice, with defaults linux and amd64. This is a pretty exciting change, because it means down the line you (as a user!) can specify the specifics of the layers you want returned, given an image that has this metadata available. We can see the fix running as follows:DEBUG *** STARTING DOCKER IMPORT PYTHON ****This is the initialization of the Docker client, it’s parsing the image name providedDEBUG Starting Docker IMPORT, includes env, runscript, and metadata.VERBOSE Docker image: ubuntu:14.04VERBOSE2 Specified Docker ENTRYPOINT as %runscript.DEBUG Headers found: Content-Type,AcceptVERBOSE Registry: index.docker.ioVERBOSE Namespace: libraryVERBOSE Repo Name: ubuntuVERBOSE Repo Tag: 14.04VERBOSE Version: NoneThe initial poke to Docker hub asks for tags, to determine if we need some kind of tokenVERBOSE Obtaining tags: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/listDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/list401> means that we do, and with the response the API sends back the scope and other details we need to make to request itDEBUG Http Error with code 401Here we are requesting itDEBUG GET <https://auth.docker.io/token?service=registry.docker.io&expires_in=9000&scope=repository:library/ubuntu:pullDEBUG> Headers found: Content-Type,Authorization,AcceptAnd here is the new bit. Instead of blindly doing one call, we have a function to update two versions of the manifest - the older (with metadata) and some version of the newer (with layers and size) with a fallback to use the version 1DEBUG Updating manifests.# Here is version 2+DEBUG MANIFEST (Primary): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latest#> Here is version 1 (Metadata)DEBUG MANIFEST (Metadata): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestNotice> that the two calls are the same - that’s because the headers are actually different, to request different ones.And here is the (new) indication that we found a listDEBUG Image manifest version 2.2 list found.Here is the default architecture / osDEBUG Obtaining architecture: amd64, OS: linuxAnd the specific call to get itVERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afWith> this fix - we can again use pull/import, etc, and also have a working singularity pull <docker://busybox> that estimates the size automatically.Please report any additional bugs to our issues board. Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Sep 15, 2017

if [ -n "${SINGULARITY_BTSTRP_2EXISTING:-}" ]; then # we are bootstrapping to an existing image and need to populate the rootfs

attachments.title: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity 2.3.2 Quick Fix Release Sep 15, 2017 / Release 2.3.2 This dot release includes a fix for a change that Docker implemented to their registry RESTful API which broke compatibility with Singularity (among several other low minor fixes).What happened?Where does Docker image metadata come from?The Docker Registry serves metadata about images via manifests, where each image has a manifest that tells Singularity important information like environment, labels, and entrypoints and running command. Importantly, the image manifest serves the actual layers that should be obtained to create the image. The manifests come in different flavors, or schema versions. Version 1 serves the primary load of metadata (labels, environment) while the first release of version 2 served layers, and had the addition of size. This addition made it possible to pull an image with Singularity and calculate the size on the fly for images generated with support for this manifest.Singularity had an old default to retrieve the version 2 (done by way of a header asking for it), and ask it for layers. If the remote registry could only offer version 1, we were still able to obtain a list of layers (under a different key, fsLayers instead of layers) and metadata via the older (schema 1) manifest. However, with the update, the API version 2 schema can now return a list of manifests. This meant that when we checked the response for the keys layers or fslayers, they wouldn’t be found, becaues we needed to look under manifests, and then do a second call to retrieve the manifest of interest based on a system architecture and OS. This of course broke most import, shell, pull, exec, because all of these commands require retrieving the layers.The PatchA super quick fix would have been to fall back to the version 1 manifest, always, but then we would lose the automatic calculation of size, which is important to many users. The “better” fix is obvious - the code needs to: check for a manifests key if found, select a default manifest to use retrieve it, and continue! if not found, fall back to version 1This means that we’ve added environment variables SINGULARITY_DOCKER_OS and SINGULARITY_DOCKER_ARCHITECTURE to specify this choice, with defaults linux and amd64. This is a pretty exciting change, because it means down the line you (as a user!) can specify the specifics of the layers you want returned, given an image that has this metadata available. We can see the fix running as follows:DEBUG *** STARTING DOCKER IMPORT PYTHON ****This is the initialization of the Docker client, it’s parsing the image name providedDEBUG Starting Docker IMPORT, includes env, runscript, and metadata.VERBOSE Docker image: ubuntu:14.04VERBOSE2 Specified Docker ENTRYPOINT as %runscript.DEBUG Headers found: Content-Type,AcceptVERBOSE Registry: index.docker.ioVERBOSE Namespace: libraryVERBOSE Repo Name: ubuntuVERBOSE Repo Tag: 14.04VERBOSE Version: NoneThe initial poke to Docker hub asks for tags, to determine if we need some kind of tokenVERBOSE Obtaining tags: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/listDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/ubuntu/tags/list401> means that we do, and with the response the API sends back the scope and other details we need to make to request itDEBUG Http Error with code 401Here we are requesting itDEBUG GET <https://auth.docker.io/token?service=registry.docker.io&expires_in=9000&scope=repository:library/ubuntu:pullDEBUG> Headers found: Content-Type,Authorization,AcceptAnd here is the new bit. Instead of blindly doing one call, we have a function to update two versions of the manifest - the older (with metadata) and some version of the newer (with layers and size) with a fallback to use the version 1DEBUG Updating manifests.# Here is version 2+DEBUG MANIFEST (Primary): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latest#> Here is version 1 (Metadata)DEBUG MANIFEST (Metadata): not found, making initial call.VERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/latestNotice> that the two calls are the same - that’s because the headers are actually different, to request different ones.And here is the (new) indication that we found a listDEBUG Image manifest version 2.2 list found.Here is the default architecture / osDEBUG Obtaining architecture: amd64, OS: linuxAnd the specific call to get itVERBOSE Obtaining manifest: <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afDEBUG> GET <https://index.docker.io/v2/library/busybox/manifests/sha256:030fcb92e1487b18c974784dcc110a93147c9fc402188370fbfd17efabffc6afWith> this fix - we can again use pull/import, etc, and also have a working singularity pull <docker://busybox> that estimates the size automatically.Please report any additional bugs to our issues board. Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Sep 15, 2017

text: See this GitHub repo for a more thorough example.  The container “installs” some binaries in your home directory using this strategy.
Users never even knew they were using a container.  :slightly_smiling_face:
I used this strategy at NIH extensively to install apps on Biowulf.
If the directory is added to the path, each symlink appears to be a binary that is actually executed inside the container.

```
$ ln -s wrapper cmd1
$ ln -s wrapper cmd2
...
```
Then make links to the wrapper script like so:

```#!/bin/bash
# if you want to bind some host directories...
# export SINGULARTY_BINDPATH=/some,/dirs,/to,/bind
dir=$(dirname  "$0")
cmd=$(basename "$0")
arg="$@"
singularity exec $dir/image $cmd $arg```
You can write a wrapper script of the following form

attachments.title: Building an Ubuntu image on a RHEL host | Singularity
attachments.text: Building an Ubuntu image on a RHEL host Sep 23, 2016 / This recipe describes how to build an Ubuntu image using Singularity on a RHEL compatible host.NOTE: this tutorial is intended for Singularity release 2.1.2, and reflects standards for that <http://version.In|version.In> order to do this, you will need to first install the ‘debootstrap’ package onto your host. Then, you will create a definition file that will describe how to build your Ubuntu image. Finally, you will build the image using the Singularity commands ‘create’ and bootstrap.PreparationThis recipe assumes that you have already installed Singularity on your computer. If you have not, follow the instructions here to install. After Singularity is installed on your computer, you will need to install the ‘debootstrap’ package. The ‘debootstrap’ package is a tool that will allow you to create Debian-based distributions such as Ubuntu. In order to install ‘debootstrap’, you will also need to install ‘epel-release’. You will need to download the appropriate RPM from the EPEL website. Make sure you download the correct version of the RPM for your release.# First, wget the appropriate RPM from the EPEL website (<https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/>)# In this example we used RHEL 7, so we downloaded epel-release-latest-7.noarch.rpm$ wget <https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/epel-release-latest-7.noarch.rpm#> Then, install your epel-release RPM$ sudo yum install epel-release-latest-7.noarch.rpm # Finally, install debootstrap$ sudo yum install debootstrapCreating the Definition FileYou will need to create a definition file to describe how to build your Ubuntu image. Definition files are plaintext files that contain Singularity keywords. By using certain Singularity keywords, you can specify how you want your image to be built. The extension ‘.def’ is recommended for user clarity. Below is a definition file for a minimal Ubuntu image: DistType

I just want to put it out there that "Rebuildability" is great. However, only being able to do recipe builds would significantly reduce the utility of Singularity for us. Some recipes for tough cases will take a long time to develop and under time pressure we must be able to throw together a writable container like we can today, get a writable shell inside, and hammer out a working solution to a local client in a short time without spending 2 weeks on a rebuildable recipe. text: Can you raise an issue?
:bug:
I agree with you.  It is weird that both `-c` and `-H` are necessary to get this to work.  It should just work with `-c`.
Oh you know what?  When I was testing it in the container I did `ls -l ~` but since `$HOME=/mnt` this just shows the contents of `/mnt`.  When I do `ls -l /home/ubuntu` I see foo as I expect.
You are right.  This works for me with 2.3.1-dist.
Your home directory is mounted twice in the container?
OK.  Maybe I’ll roll back to the dist version and try again.
the behavior I see is consistent with the help message: `dest overrides the home directory within the container`

Here’s mine
```$ singularity --version
2.3.1-master.gd2cbd51```
Can you provide the output of `singularity -v`
You do? Weird, I don't
<https://gist.github.com/remram44/7cc703128d0c5d7193dbde64655ac04a>

You must be doing something different than me.  I shelled into the container as root and created `/home/ubuntu` (the user on my VM) and then I touched `foo`.  When I issued shell with `-C` and `H $HOME:/mnt` I still saw the contents of the system `/home/ubuntu` at `/home/ubuntu` within the container (in addition to seeing the contents of `/home/ubuntu` at `/mnt`.)
if I put that out of the way, outside of `/home`, then Singularity lets me see the `/home` from the image
Well the good thing about -H is that it also allow me to set an alternate location for $HOME inside the container
That’s not what you want right?
Also, I wonder if the `-H` option is working the way you think it is.  I think it is just going to show you the home directory on the host system and not the home directory within the container.
This yielded unusual results.
I guess you could create it manually, but that’s not the expectation.  I just shelled into a container as root and created a `/home/$USER` directory.
`/home/$USER` is not created during the bootstrap procedure.
But I guess the expectation is that a container will not have it’s own `/home/$USER`.

Normally when you shell into a container (or exec or whatever) you’re home directory is visible to you.  This is the home directory on the host system.  It’s shared within the container.   You can write to it and everything.  Same with /tmp and /dev and I think also $PWD.  `-c` turns that off.
> -c/--contain  This option disables the sharing of filesystems on your host (e.g. /dev, $HOME and /tmp).
to be honest I don't understand what `-c` does at all, since it doesn't leave `/home` alone
using `-H` works around this but it just seemed, from reading the help string for `-c`, that just using `-c` would have done that
I'm using this for ReproZip so I don't really control that (the package is what it is)
So unless you have a good reason (which you totally might) I would suggest put your stuff somewhere else.
It’s not really the _Singularity_ way to do things.
As you’ve noticed `/home` is a special directory in Singularity so if you are trying to put things there it’s probably not going to work as expected.
Maybe I should back up and ask you what you are trying to do that you need a `/home` directory for the user in the container.

Can you verify somehow that the tarball actually does have a home directory in it?

huh, can you give a definition file and command to reproduce this? It might be a bug

I want to see the `/home` directory included in the image rather than have the host's home directory mounted in the container
Am I missing something?
So it should not be surprising that when you use `-c` you cannot see `~`.

```    -c/--contain        This option disables the sharing of filesystems on
                        your host (e.g. /dev, $HOME and /tmp).```
If you type `singularity shell help` you will see these lines:

text: A use case of writable: I use it a bit like qlogin on the cluster. To see inside a job interactively. If I install the centos 7 build using yum, I am missing basic tools such as awk, find, less etc. To install cuda on top of that fails due to missing apps. until I go through the whole process of finding where the build fails each time. Using writable allows me to yum install the app and carry on trying the cuda install until I find all the missing apps. Building from scratch each time takes ages, for it to fail, fix the issue then repeat the rebuild and fail cycle again, and using docker provides a different set of packages in the image, so it's not comparable.
And would be broken quicker than other means of providing apps
<@U245DTC59> however a badly built or non future proof container may not be buildable after centos 7.4 is released, or new Ubuntu LTS etc
Notice the working ubuntu container is only 44MB!

This thread has exploded, and I think <@U245DTC59> mentioned it above, but It would greatly benefit our potential usage here if singularity could run docker images without having to go through a multi-step conversion process. 

For HPC, there's been some movement to provide docker images, and this works fine on an individual workstation.  Docker has issues with the "run as root" default, this makes it hard to support on a cluster, especially with root-squashed NFS mounts and the like.  Singularity seems to get around that and run as $USER, but it's much easier to build and share a Docker image or Dockerfile.

plain_text: I'd probably favour a dockerized solution. Would be nice to have be able to start everything up with docker-compose. Also, as it's an 'infrastructure' web service would be good to be able to use docker's layering and security scan tools (like clair) to aid keeping things up to date. Easier to manage updates to an e.g. docker DB container than if there's a singularity image with everything in? That said, either singularity or docker works for me.

    -B/--bind <spec>    A user-bind path specification.  spec has the format

                        to src.  Mount options ('opts') may be specified as
                        'ro' (read-only) or 'rw' (read/write, which is the 
                        default). This option can be called multiple times.
```

Interesting! I'll be able to try the daemon version on my laptop. Thanks!

From your question it sounds like you want the web server and iptables within the container? With the current version, you would do best to run and control via the host, and the container should share that like it does a web server (but this should be tested). If you intend to have something working from inside the container (eg, installing inside the container and expecting to start/stop/restart) what would happen with the current version is you would lose control of the process after exiting (I think this is called a ghost process). But there is something new and cool to try! <@U2MQD256V> has been working on having support for service daemons: <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/tree/feature-daemon> so you could write a "start script" to start iptables, and then still have control on the host. We've been testing it a bit and your feedback would be hugely great! :O)

If you do this on a shared system it’s possible for you to install containerized apps and for users to run those apps without ever knowing what a container is, much less how to use one with singularity.

You can recreate this basic structure with any image (using any installation method you like) and it will expose binaries within the container to the outside world so that the container is completely transparent to the user.

There you will find
1. An image
2. A wrapper script
3. Some links to the wrapper script that end up looking like executables
Instead you should just run it and then pay attention to the new subdirectory that gets created in your home directory.
Basically if you are just interested in running commands inside the container from outside of the container you should not try to read the Singularity file.
The lolcow RUN script doesn’t have anything to do with how this works because it gets overwritten by the %runscript portion of the lolcow-installer singularity file.

hey everyone! I have been working on something I think is very important - a simple format specification for the internal guts of a Singularity image, one that will make it easy to define different modules within your container, and then connect / export / import / bootstrap in an equivalent fashion. I am aiming to write this up for scientific data, and want to get as many contributors as are interested - contributor == author. You can comment and make suggestions directly on the draft: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1k0I1M1BIR1aqGxVVJrow_Gj3T8BXHco-oqnreYKuxL8/edit?usp=sharing> and see the current implementation here <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/pull/826> I'm announcing here to get your feedback first, and then will announce more publicly. <https://www.nature.com/subjects/data-publication-and-archiving>

text:
Hi <!channel> ,

I'm currently working on the implementation of daemon support in Singularity and it's at the point that we think people can be testing and playing with it! I would like to invite everybody to check out <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/tree/feature-daemon> where you can download and build what I've been working on. `singularity start <container path> <daemon name>` will create a "daemon container", which is a container inside a PID namespace that contains a singularity controlled init process (named sinit). Using this feature, there is now proper handling of cleanup. For instance, if you enter a daemon container with shell, start my-sql, then exit the shell back to the host, my-sql will continue running inside the container. A `singularity stop <container path> <daemon name>` pointed at the daemon you just entered will properly clean up and close everything in the namespace as expected now.

The following snippet is a bit of a showcase of what this looks like right now!

If you come across any issues, or come up with any suggestions, post an issue on GitHub. Also, if you want to contribute you can submit a pull request to the `feature-daemon` branch. Here is an incomplete list of things that still need to be worked on:

```
1) Help files for stop and list commands [libexec/cli/stop.help /list.help]
2) Tab autocomplete for start and stop don't work at all :disappointed:
3) Documentation for the website (how to, best practices, examples, etc...)
4) We need test scripts in tests/ [maybe tests/XX-daemon.sh]
5) %startscript - This should be a new section in a bootstrap file that specifies behavior of the container when you do singularity start <container path> <daemon name>. For instance, a my-sql.img container could have a startscript start my-sql in the container.
```

if you pull `<shub://myname/mycontainer:<mytag>>` you would expect to get the last frozen / done version of the tag, and only if you add a specific <shub://myname/mycontainer:<version>> should you expect to get one exact commit

hey all, want to bring this issue to your attention as <@U245DTC59> suggested :slightly_smiling_face: So far, tagging is restricted to branch names, and a future release of shub will search for multiple Singularity files and create automatic tags from the file ending. But what I still miss, is kind of a frozen container tag, that holds a snaphost of a container build from a certain bootstrap.  Such that when I pull with `<shub://myname/mycontainer:<mytag>>` and use this in different workflows, I know that this is indeed the same container (with  a certain versions of software I installed inside, for example).  I mean <@U245DTC59>, the tagging as you intend to do it is nice, and desirable for different use cases (tagging development or feature branches), but could be extended with fixed (time) version tags, such as `<shub://myname/mycontainer:<mytag>-<version>>`. Just as an idea :slightly_smiling_face: <https://github.com/singularityhub/singularityhub.github.io/issues/43#issuecomment-316209398>

text: The easiest thing is probably to maintain one Dockerfile and then just convert to singularity

part of this is really about cost of maintenance - whether  we should maintain a Dockerfile and a Singularityfile or just use something like <http://packer.io|packer.io> to generate whatever image whereever.

I didn't put much thought into it, I chose to compile because I wanted complete control over versions, and I wanted to implement the exact same thing in the Dockerfile and Singularity file. If I just pulled from another Docker image depending on the tag I use, I'm not guaranteed using the same thing, and it's again reliant on layers of things instead of the whole thing. It probably doesn't matter too much, but that was what felt right at the time.

the issue comes down to the application's database - it's easy for an institution because they will use "real" databases like postgre /sqlite, that are external to the (sometimes read only) registry image

thats why the `singularity check ubuntu.img` workflow shouldn't implement a fix (which is more appropriate for bootstrap)
what I'm hoping is that there could be robust checks that a user is allowed to run, so he/she can make an image, and then choose some check group to run, and get feedback about better practices

they don't have to be security, they can be like "does this image have the right version of X and Y and Z? is it web ready? is the OS something specific? are permissions on this thing ok? does it have the folders to run on this cluster? etc"
because the idea of the checks folder is that it should be easy for admins to add custom checks, and people ideally will contribute PRs with various checks they think are important
and if it does happen at bootstrap, it's not enough to say that "fix X was performed" we would want to capture the fix command in some more reproducible way.

one thing I'm not decided on (for which your feedback would be good) is how to act on FAIL tests. Right now the check doesn't do anything but print a status, and I was thinking there could be an option (given appropriate permissions) to fix the image. The issue with this, however, is that it's not captured that it was fixed in metadata or the bootstrap file, so we would need to either require fixes to happen only at bootstrap, and then allow checks after bootstrap (but no fix option, or for a user developing an image, an instruction on how to fix that he/she can add to the bootstrap file

<@U2MT7BF0V> Just for my understanding, do you mean that caching will not happen for read-write data or you mean it will simply be inefficient because of invalidation on write?

I don’t think it has to do with it being a single file vs many.  Because after it is mounted a container is also a lot of files.  I think the key is really that it is *read only*.  That’s what allows it to be cached.
And because singularity container is only one file ? At the opposite, if you have many versions you need to stat/read it again ? It is no more cached. ??

<@U4BKCNE9K> <@U2MT7BF0V> that was my interpretation - the container contents are cached and metadata queries from the perspective of the application in the container (e.g. stat calls on libraries in the python sys.path) become cached data reads from the perspective of the shared NFS file system.

<@U4BKCNE9K> I think the key to <@U3NE4A4M8> ‘s benchmarks that you are referencing is that the container is mounted as read only.  This allows the kernel to cache the contents and then when python starts opening thousands or 10s of thousands of files, they are all cached instead of being on network storage somewhere. attachments.title: Create an Image | Singularity
attachments.text: Create an Image A Singularity image, which can be referred to as a “container,” is a single file that contains a virtual file system. After creating an image you can install an operating system, applications, and save meta-data with it.Whereas Docker assembles images from layers that are stored on your computer (viewed with the docker -ps command), a Singularity image is just one file that can sit on your Desktop, in a folder on your cluster, or anywhere.Having Singularity containers housed within a single image file greatly simplifies management tasks such as sharing, copying, and branching your containers. It also means that standard Linux file system concepts like permissions, ownership, and ACLs apply to the container (e.g. I can give read only access to a colleague, or block access completely with a simple chmod command).Creating a new blank Singularity container imageSingularity will create a default container image of 768MiB using the following command:$ singularity create container.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container.imgCreating 768MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container.imgHow big is it?$ du -sh container.img 29M container.imgWe can now use ls to list details about the image.$ ls -l container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 805306400 Apr 15 11:11 container.imgNote the permissions of the image make it executable. Singularity images can be executed directly.Creating an image of a different sizeYou can change the maximum size of an image you create using the --size option. Note that --size is not a global option. It is an option to the create sub-command and must therefore follow it:$ singularity create --size 2048 container2.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container2.imgCreating 2048MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container2.img$ ls -lh container*.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 2.1G Apr 15 11:34 container2.img-rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.imgOverwriting an image with a new oneIf you have already created an image and wish to overwrite it, you can do so with the --force option. This option must also follow the create sub-command.$ singularity create --size 512 --force container2.imgInitializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container2.imgCreating 512MiB imageBinding image to loopCreating file system within imageImage is done: container2.img$ ls -lh container*.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 513M Apr 15 11:39 container2.img-rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.imgShow Video Tutorial Increasing the size of an existing imageYou can increase the size of an image after it has been instantiated by using the expand Singularity sub-command as follows:$ ls -lh container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 769M Apr 15 11:11 container.img$ singularity expand container.img Initializing Singularity image subsystemOpening image file: container.imgExpanding image by 768MiBBinding image to loopChecking file systeme2fsck 1.42.13 (17-May-2015)Pass 1: Checking inodes, blocks, and sizesPass 2: Checking directory structurePass 3: Checking directory connectivityPass 4: Checking reference countsPass 5: Checking group summary information/dev/loop0: 11/49152 files (0.0% non-contiguous), 7387/196608 blocksResizing file systemresize2fs 1.42.13 (17-May-2015)Resizing the filesystem on /dev/loop0 to 393216 (4k) blocks.The filesystem on /dev/loop0 is now 393216 (4k) blocks long.Image is done: container.img$ ls -lh container.img -rwxr-xr-x 1 user group 1.6G Apr 15 12:21 container.imgSimilar to the create sub-command, you can override the default size increase (which is 768MiB) by using the --size option.Show Video Tutorial Mounting an imageOnce an image has been created and an OS has been added with the import or bootstrap commands, you can use the shell command to start an interactive shell within the container. But this is not possible when an image does not yet contain a functional OS or shell. For debugging, development, or simply inspecting an image that lacks a functional shell you can use the mount command like so:$ mkdir /tmp/container$ singularity mount container.img /tmp/container/container.img is mounted at: /tmp/container/Spawning a new shell in this namespace, to unmount, exit shellSingularity: \w> dfFilesystem 1K-blocks Used Available Use% Mounted on/dev/loop0 1531760 1172 1451948 1% /tmp/containerSingularity: \w> cd /tmp/containerSingularity: \w> ls -a. .. lost+foundShow Video Tutorial At this point the image just contains a bare file system because we haven’t used something like the bootstrap or import commands to install an OS.Singularity mounts images in private name-spaces so that the mount is only visible and accessible from within the freshly spawned shell. When you are finished, you can simply exit the shell and the file system will be automatically unmounted.Files can be copied from the image to the host when it is mounted in this way, but they cannot be copied from the host into the image. This is because the image is mounted in read-only mode by default and the mount point is owned by the root user. To copy files into a mounted image, first become root and then mount the image with the --writable option to the mount sub-command.$ sudo -i# singularity mount --writable /home/user/container.img /tmp/containerShow Video Tutorial Copying, sharing, branching, and distributing your imageA primary goal of Singularity is mobility. The single file image format makes mobility easy.Because Singularity images are single files, they are easily copied and managed. You can copy the image to create a branch, share the image and distribute the image as easily as copying any other file you control!If you want an automated solution for building and hosting your image, you can use our container registry Singularity Hub. Singulairty Hub can automatically build bootstrap specification files from a Github repository each time that you push. It provides a simple cloud solution for storing and sharing your image. Previous Next Site last generated: Jul 2, 2017

attachments.title: Singularity on HPC | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity on HPC One of the architecturally defined features in Singularity is that it can execute containers like they are native programs or scripts on a host computer. As a result, integration with schedulers is simple and runs exactly as you would expect. All standard input, output, error, pipes, IPC, and other communication pathways that locally running programs employ are synchronized with the applications running locally within the container.Additionally, because Singularity is not emulating a full hardware level virtualization paradigm, there is no need to separate out any sandboxed networks or file systems because there is no concept of user-escalation within a container. Users can run Singularity containers just as they run any other program on the HPC resource.WorkflowsWe are in the process of developing Singularity Hub, which will allow for generation of workflows using Singularity containers in an online interface, and easy deployment on standard research clusters (e.g., SLURM, SGE). Currently, the Singularity core software is installed on the following research clusters, meaning you can run Singularity containers as part of your jobs: The Sherlock cluster at Stanford University SDSC Comet and Gordon (XSEDE) MASSIVE M1 M2 and M3 (Monash University and Australian National Merit Allocation Scheme)Integration with MPIAnother result of the Singularity architecture is the ability to properly integrate with the Message Passing Interface (MPI). Work has already been done for out of the box compatibility with Open MPI (both in Open MPI v2.1.x as well as part of Singularity). The Open MPI/Singularity workflow works as follows: mpirun is called by the resource manager or the user directly from a shell Open MPI then calls the process management daemon (ORTED) The ORTED process launches the Singularity container requested by the mpirun command Singularity builds the container and namespace environment Singularity then launches the MPI application within the container The MPI application launches and loads the Open MPI libraries The Open MPI libraries connect back to the ORTED process via the Process Management Interface (PMI) At this point the processes within the container run as they would normally directly on the host.This entire process happens behind the scenes, and from the user’s perspective running via MPI is as simple as just calling mpirun on the host as they would normally.Below are example snippets of building and installing OpenMPI into a container and then running an example MPI program through Singularity.Tutorials Using Host libraries: GPU drivers and OpenMPI BTLsMPI Development ExampleWhat are supported Open MPI Version(s)?To achieve proper container’ized Open MPI support, you should use Open MPI version 2.1. There are however three caveats: Open MPI 1.10.x may work but we expect you will need exactly matching version of PMI and Open MPI on both host and container (the 2.1 series should relax this requirement) Open MPI 2.1.0 has a bug affecting compilation of libraries for some interfaces (particularly Mellanox interfaces using libmxm are known to fail). If your in this situation you should usethe master branch of Open MPI rather than the release. Using Open MPI 2.1 does not magically allow your container to connect to networking fabric libraries in the host. If your cluster has, for example, an infiniband network you still need to install OFED libraries into the container. Alternatively you could bind mount both Open MPI and networking libraries into the container, but this could run afoul of glib compatibility issues (its generally OK if the container glibc is more recent than the host, but not the other way around)Code Example using Open MPI 2.1.0 Stable$ # Include the appropriate development tools into the container (notice we are calling$ # singularity as root and the container is writeable)$ sudo singularity exec -w /tmp/Centos-7.img yum groupinstall

It says that `/home` outside the container is bind mounted to `/home` inside the container and to execute `make install` within your `/home/$USER` directory (because that is where you will start unless you use the `--pwd` option).
Note that your first example also says something a bit different:
This means that the configure commands work because they don't write to the container, but when I install I need `-w` so I can write to the container.

<@U5T7HTNCR> unless you or you admin have altered it, the `singularity.conf` file determines what directories should be bind mounted by default within the container.  `/home/$USER` is one of those.  So are things like `/tmp`, `/dev`, `/proc`…
Yet it seems that such commands work as long as you aren't trying to write to a filepath within the container.
so shouldn't the command fail?

rebuilding now!

If you want to influence the location, rebuild with the configure option `--sysconfdir=/...`

attachments.title: The Bootstrap Definition | Singularity
attachments.text: The Bootstrap Definition The process of bootstrapping a Singularity container is equivalent to describing a recipe for the container creation. There are several recipe formats that Singularity supports, but only the primary format of version 2.3 will be documented here. If you want a general overview with examples, see Bootstrapping an Image. The detailed options for each of the header and sections are provided here.The header fields:Bootstrap:The Bootstrap: keyword identifies the Singularity module that will be used for building the core components of the operating system. There are several supported modules at the time of this writing:yumThe YUM bootstrap module uses YUM on the host system to bootstrap the core operating system that exists within the container. This module is applicable for bootstrapping distributions like Red Hat, Centos, and Scientific Linux. When using the yum bootstrap module, several other keywords may also be necessary to define: MirrorURL: This is the location where the packages will be downloaded from. When bootstrapping different RHEL/YUM compatible distributions of Linux, this will define which variant will be used (e.g. the only difference in bootstrapping Centos from Scientific Linux is this line. OSVersion: When using the yum bootstrap module, this keyword is conditional and required only if you have specified a %{OSVERSION} variable name in the MirrorURL keyword. If the MirrorURL definition does not have the %{OSVERSION} variable, OSVersion can be omitted from the header field. Include: By default the core operating system is an extremely minimal base, which may or may not include the means to even install additional packages. The Include keyword should define any additional packages which should be used and installed as part of the core operating system bootstrap. The best practice is to keep this keyword usage as minimal as possible such that you can then use the %inside scriptlet (explained shortly) to do additional installations. One common package you may want to include here is yum itself.Warning, there is a major limitation with using YUM to bootstrap a container and that is the RPM database that exists within the container will be created using the RPM library and Berkeley DB implementation that exists on the host system. If the RPM implementation inside the container is not compatible with the RPM database that was used to create the container, once the container has been created RPM and YUM commands inside the container may fail. This issue can be easily demonstrated by bootstrapping an older RHEL compatible image by a newer one (e.g. bootstrap a Centos 5 or 6 container from a Centos 7 host).debootstrapThe Debian bootstrap module is a tool which is used specifically for bootstrapping distributions which utilize the .deb package format and apt-get repositories. This module will bootstrap any of the Debian and Ubuntu based distributions. When using the debootstrap module, the following keywords must also be defined: MirrorURL: This is the location where the packages will be downloaded from. When bootstrapping different Debian based distributions of Linux, this will define which varient will be used (e.g. specifying a different URL can be the difference between Debian or Ubuntu). OSVersion: This keyword must be defined as the alpha-character string associated with the version of the distribution you wish to use. For example, trusty or stable. Include: As with the yum module, the Include keyword will install additional packages into the core operating system and the best practice is to supply only the bare essentials such that the %inside scriptlet has what it needs to properly completely the bootstrap.archThe Arch Linux bootstrap module does not name any additional keywords at this time. By defining the arch module, you have essentially given all of the information necessary for that particular bootstrap module to build a core operating system.dockerThe Docker bootstrap module will create a core operating system image based on an image hosted on a particular Docker Registry server. By default it will use the primary Docker Library, but that can be overridden. When using the docker module, several other keywords may also be defined: From: This keyword defines the string of the registry name used for this image in the format [name]:[version]. Several examples are: ubuntu:latest, centos:6, alpine:latest, or debian (if the version tag is ommitted, :latest is automatically used). IncludeCmd: This keyword tells Singularity to utilize the Docker defined Cmd as the %runscript (defined below), if the Cmd is defined. Registry: If the registry you wish to download the image from is not from the main Docker Library, you can define it here. Token: Sometimes the Docker API (depending on version?) requires an authorization token which is generated on the fly. Toggle this with a yes or no here.Bootstrap sections:Once the Bootstrap module has completed, the sections are identified and utilized if present. The following sections are supported in the bootstrap definition, and integrated during the bootstrap process:%setupThis section blob is a Bourne shell scriptlet which will be executed on the host outside the container during bootstrap. The path to the container is accessible from within the running scriptlet environment via the variable $SINGULARITY_ROOTFS. For example, consider the following scriptlet:%setup echo

From now, my list is the following:
  - the kernel version
  - the way you compile/recompile your program if it's needed
  - libraries used and their versions
  - processor type (Intel, AMD), arch (32/64) and its features (SSE, AVX...).
  - locales, encoding
  - local time
  - some devices, and specific character devides (eg: /dev/urandom)

text: I'll submit a pull request to fix this bug  in 2.3

I just changed etc/singularity/init to 
if [[ "x${SINGULARITYENV_PATH}" == "x" ]]; then
           SINGULARITYENV_PATH="/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin"
fi
and now SINGULARITYENV_PATH works inside the container!
I can confirm it since setting SINGULARITYENV_PATH in my environment before running singularity shell shows that only the above hardcoded value is present.

Looking at etc/init in the singularity source it looks like SINGULARITYENV_PATH might simply be overwritten and non-usable
SINGULARITYENV_PATH="/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin"
Why, oh why?

Why don't you try bootstrapping a new image from scratch in 2.3 (not overwriting one that already exists).  Add an `export PATH=/my/stuff:$PATH` to the `%environment` section and then shell in, and check out your path.  I'm guessing your stuff will be on the path. You can theoretically setup a way to SSH into a running singularity image on a remote host... but, there isn't a good way. The basic workflow as it stands is mpiexec calls the image, and the image is stand alone. It doesn't try to make its own MPI calls... since then you're trying to setup a MPI session that an image has no easy way of connecting to. <@U115P26TB> had some thoughts on how to make it feasible... but IIRC, that was in the 0.x days :/

attachments.title: Install on Linux | Singularity
attachments.text: Install on Linux Installation from SourceYou can try the following two options:Option 1: Download latest stable releaseYou can always download the latest tarball release from GithubFor example, here is how to download version 2.3 and install:VERSION=2.3wget <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/releases/download/$VERSION/singularity-$VERSION.tar.gztar> xvf singularity-$VERSION.tar.gzcd singularity-$VERSION./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installOption 2: Download the latest development codeTo download the most recent development code, you should use Git and do the following:git clone <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity.gitcd> singularity./autogen.sh./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installnote: The ‘make install’ is required to be run as root to get a properly installed Singularity implementation. If you do not run it as root, you will only be able to launch Singularity as root due to permission limitations.Show Video Tutorial UpdatingTo update your Singularity version, you might want to first delete the executables for the old version:sudo rm -rf /usr/local/libexec/singularityAnd then install using one of the methods above.Debian/Ubuntu PackageSingularity is available on Debian (and Ubuntu) systems starting with Debian stretch and the Ubuntu 16.10 yakkety releases. The package is called singularity-container. For recent releases of singularity and backports for older Debian and Ubuntu releases, we recommend that you use the NeuroDebian repository.Testing first with DockerIf you want a quick preview of the NeuroDebian mirror, you can do this most easily with the NeuroDebian Docker image (and if you don’t, skip to the next section). Obviously you should have Docker installed before you do this.First we run the neurodebian Docker image:$ docker run -it --rm neurodebianThen we update the cache (very quietly), and look at the singularity-container policy provided:$ apt-get update -qqq$ apt-cache policy singularity-containersingularity-container: Installed: (none) Candidate: 2.3-1~nd80+1 Version table: 2.3-1~nd80+1 0 500 <http://neuro.debian.net/debian/> jessie/main amd64 PackagesYou can continue worker in Docker, or go back to your host and install Singularity.Adding the Mirror and InstallingYou should first enable the NeuroDebian repository following instructions on the NeuroDebian site. This means using the dropdown menus to find the correct mirror for your operating system and location. For example, after selecting Ubuntu 16.04 and selecting a mirror in CA, I am instructed to add these lists:sudo wget -O- <http://neuro.debian.net/lists/xenial.us-ca.full> | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/neurodebian.sources.listsudo apt-key adv --recv-keys --keyserver <hkp://pool.sks-keyservers.net:80> 0xA5D32F012649A5A9and then updatesudo apt-get updatethen singularity can be installed as follows:sudo apt-get install -y singularity-containerDuring the above, if you have a previously installed configuration, you might be asked if you want to define a custom configuration/init, or just use the default provided by the package, eg:Configuration file '/etc/singularity/init' ==> File on system created by you or by a script. ==> File also in package provided by package maintainer. What would you like to do about it ? Your options are: Y or I : install the package maintainer's version N or O : keep your currently-installed version D : show the differences between the versions Z : start a shell to examine the situation The default action is to keep your current version.*** init (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ? YConfiguration file '/etc/singularity/singularity.conf' ==> File on system created by you or by a script. ==> File also in package provided by package maintainer. What would you like to do about it ? Your options are: Y or I : install the package maintainer's version N or O : keep your currently-installed version D : show the differences between the versions Z : start a shell to examine the situation The default action is to keep your current version.*** singularity.conf (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ? YAnd for a user, it’s probably well suited to use the defaults. For a cluster admin, we recommend that you read the admin docs to get a better understanding of the configuration file options available to you. Remember that you can always tweak the files at /etc/singularity/singularity.conf and /etc/singularity/init if you want to make changes.After this install, you should confirm that 2.3-dist is the version installed:$ singularity --version 2.3-distNote that if you don’t add the NeuroDebian lists, the version provided will be old (e.g., 2.2.1). If you need a backport build of the recent release of Singularity on those or older releases of Debian and Ubuntu, you can see all the various builds and other information here.Build an RPM from sourceLike the above, you can build an RPM of Singularity so it can be more easily managed, upgraded and removed. From the base Singularity source directory do the following:./autogen.sh./configuremake distrpmbuild -ta singularity-*.tar.gzsudo yum install ~/rpmbuild/RPMS/*/singularity-[0-9]*.rpmNote: if you want to have the RPM install the files to an alternative location, you should define the environment variable ‘PREFIX’ to suit your needs, and use the following command to build:PREFIX=/opt/singularityrpmbuild -ta --define=

attachments.title: Install on Linux | Singularity
attachments.text: Install on Linux Installation from SourceYou can try the following two options:Option 1: Download latest stable releaseYou can always download the latest tarball release from GithubFor example, here is how to download version 2.2.1 and install:VERSION=2.2.1wget <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity/releases/download/$VERSION/singularity-$VERSION.tar.gztar> xvf singularity-$VERSION.tar.gzcd singularity-$VERSION./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installOption 2: Download the latest development codeTo download the most recent development code, you should use Git and do the following:git clone <https://github.com/singularityware/singularity.gitcd> singularity./autogen.sh./configure --prefix=/usr/localmakesudo make installnote: The ‘make install’ is required to be run as root to get a properly installed Singularity implementation. If you do not run it as root, you will only be able to launch Singularity as root due to permission limitations.Show Video Tutorial UpdatingTo update your Singularity version, you might want to first delete the executables for the old version:sudo rm -rf /usr/local/libexec/singularityAnd then install using one of the methods above.Build an RPM from sourceLike the above, you can build an RPM of Singularity so it can be more easily managed, upgraded and removed. From the base Singularity source directory do the following:./autogen.sh./configuremake distrpmbuild -ta singularity-*.tar.gzsudo yum install ~/rpmbuild/RPMS/*/singularity-[0-9]*.rpmNote: if you want to have the RPM install the files to an alternative location, you should define the environment variable ‘PREFIX’ to suit your needs, and use the following command to build:PREFIX=/opt/singularityrpmbuild -ta --define=

attachments.text: Singularity 2.3 Release May 31, 2017 / We have some egg-citing news! It’s the release of Singularity 2.3!For the full release announcement and downloads, please see the release on Github.There are a massive number of fixes, updates, optimizations and awesomeness contained within this release, and here are the major ones, in a nutshell: Lots of backend library changes to accommodate a more flexible API Restructured Python backend Updated bootstrap backend to make it much more reliable Direct support for Singularity-Hub Ability to run additional commands without root privileges (e.g. create, import, copy, export, etc..). Added ability to pull images from Singularity Hub and Docker Containers now have labels, and are inspect’ableWe are excited about the release, and grateful to the community and all contributors. Have fun, egglings! Please report any additional bugs as issues.Thank you! Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Jun 1, 2017

I don't see how to implement just stopping all other requests given that there could be a shared cache between many users potentially, and all running different processes

unless the user asks for different location
if there's a local copy it get it otherwise start a new download, all the other requests are just stopped waiting for the running download

but yes, if there is not the complete file, the others will start their temporary downloads, and then cut when they see a finished one.
once it is downlaoded, it won't be downloaded again
the case you are talking about is when the image isn't in the cache, and it's asked for multiple times at the same time, within the time it takes to download
that's good, but ideally it should execute only one download and put all the following concurrent request for the same image

text:
This is something I've thought about for a bit. My usecase is probably a bit special (I want self-contained experiment directories for fast-changing code which include the singularity definition and are very small).
For this, I rely on the definition file (currently as stored in the container, but `inspect` looks great for that), mostly building from a dockerfile (since they will probably all contain CUDA), and I just have to hope that you can reconstruct the container from date and possibly installed versions should it become necessary to accurately reproduce an experiment.

it's a good example of a community coming together and using a standard

it's more than for files, it is also a communication protocol
a really good example is how DICOM has been developed
I too have been thinking about standards for containers
do you mean the Singularity definition file? That will be stored with the container and seeable with inspect

does anyone have a neat method for copying the source template into the container? would be nice if there was a commands such as singularity source and singularity usage which showed the template it was created with, and some custom usage info , to avoid carrying readme and template files around with the container

I think that when talking abouth HPC enviroments a good practice will be a def file from scratch, since compiling leads to a better performance than a pre-compiled binaries (may vary depending on the arch).
Something in the doc could be helpful

Hello , we are preparing to release a second pipeline based on Singularity+CWL. I am running into an issue because in UBUNTU14.04 , python multiprocessing needs the OS to create temporary files in /run/shm and /run/lock.
This issue seems to be related  to the one discussed here : <https://groups.google.com/a/lbl.gov/forum/#!searchin/singularity/multiprocessing/singularity/71MhNumuMbs/H6SOkXGGCAAJ>
The most likely scenario is going to be mac users , installing Singularity according to the instructions here: <http://singularity.lbl.gov/install-mac> This results in a Ubuntu14.04 OS in the vagrant VM .That particular OS is the result of this line : vagrant init ubuntu/trusty64
The solution described in the google doc discussion was to add a line : "bind path = /run" to the /usr/loacal/etc/singularity/singularity.conf file
QUESTION: would it be feasble to add that line to the default singularity.conf file for the 2.3 singularity release ?
If not, would it be OK to change the vagrant installation instruction , so that ubuntu16.04 is used instead of 14.04 ?
Thank you!

we **can** do this, using the manifest from the registry, however it must be schema version 2.0

attachments.title: Singularity: Scientific containers for mobility of compute
attachments.text: Here we present Singularity, software developed to bring containers and reproducibility to scientific computing. Using Singularity containers, developers can work in reproducible environments of their choosing and design, and these complete environments can easily be copied and executed on other platforms. Singularity is an open source initiative that harnesses the expertise of system and software engineers and researchers alike, and integrates seamlessly into common workflows for both of these groups. As its primary use case, Singularity brings mobility of computing to both users and HPC centers, providing a secure means to capture and distribute software and compute environments. This ability to create and deploy reproducible environments across these centers, a previously unmet need, makes Singularity a game changing development for computational science.
attachments.fallback: Singularity: Scientific containers for mobility of compute

attachments.title: Getting Started with Bootstrap | Singularity
attachments.text: Getting Started with Bootstrap Previous Next Bootstrapping a ContainerBootstrapping is the process where we install an operating system and then configure it appropriately for a specified need. To do this we use a bootstrap definition file which is a recipe of how to specifically build the container and explained in detail in the previous section.For the purpose of this example, we will use the portions of the bootstrap definition file above, and assemble it into a complete definition file:# Bootstrap definition example for Centos-7 with the latest Open MPI from GitHub masterBootStrap: yumOSVersion: 7MirrorURL: <http://mirror.centos.org/centos-%{OSVERSION}/%{OSVERSION}/os/$basearch/Include>: yum%setup echo

so to answer your question directly to 1) yes, using mkdir for those folders would (I think) have them bound. And 2) --bind would work given paths that exist in both and that it's allowed in the config
given overlayfs doesn't work but the config allows user mounts, if there is a directory on the host that does exist in the container, it should bind ok

given overlayfs doesn't work on the host or it works and isn't enabled, then the config can still specify to have directories mounted, but if they don't exist in the container, they won't be created and mounted (I think this is your situation)
given that overlayfs works on the host and is enabled, when you have a directory specified to be mounted in the config, or the user asks via the --bind command, it will be mounted.

attachments.title: Singularity Big Announcement | Singularity
attachments.text: Singularity Big Announcement Apr 28, 2017 / Notice to all Singularity users, contributors, and collaboratorsThis is an important announcement from Greg Kurzer, founder and lead developer of Singularity.Singularity continues to gain popularity and traction very quickly. This growth has been extremely demanding on my time and is outpacing my ability to sustain the broad amount of use cases for the rapidly expanding community with me working on it only part time. In order to meet this rapidly expanding growth, I have created a new organization, SingularityWare, LLC, which is dedicated to further developing Singularity, supporting the associated open source community and growing the project. To facilitate this, I have partnered with a company, RStor, Inc.RStor is not only interested in the success of Singularity, as an open source, scientific enabling platform, but they are bringing their own very compelling and much needed cloud based storage/RDM platform to market. A partnership like this (containerized computing coupled with a cloud based storage platform) offers a very exciting and synergistic value to research <http://computing.In|computing.In> addition to continuing my leadership of Singularity (and the new LLC), I will be maintaining my association with Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, as a scientific advisor as well as continuing other efforts I am associated with (e.g. Warewulf and OpenHPC).This means that I now have the resources and ability to both offer support for Singularity and hire key developers, and I would like to invite interested people to send me your resume! I am looking to hire both part time and full time staff engineers as well as University collaborations to fund interns, graduates and postdocs for Singularity development and relevant involvement.Aside from additional resources, dedication, attention, and growth, the overall direction of the project will remain the same.If you have any questions, comments or want to be part of this exciting new endeavor, please feel free to contact me directly.Thank you! Please enable JavaScript to view the comments powered by Disqus. Site last generated: Apr 28, 2017

Of course, I may have misunderstood something.
if the point is already bound in the container, usually via a configuration, then it could also be skipped
now, if the administrator has disabled these custom binds, it's a no go
that command is basically a request on the level of the user asking the container to bind the host /scratch/data to /data
`singularity run -B /scratch/data:/data container.img`
in which case you would want to do like
but I think what you are trying to do is more about runtime binds

a definition file should generally create directories in the container that you want to exist, for example, I have some analysis containers that I know I'll be using on my cluster, and I do mkdir -p /scratch/PI just to do away with the warning message that it doesn't exist in the container
so then it comes down to what you would want to do in a definition file, versus runtime
if your administrator does those by default, you won't gain anything by trying to re-do them
for example home, and tmp, and on some clusters /scratch
when it comes to binding to the container itself, the administrator via this file can also define directories to be mounted by default
so the most permissive would be to allow overlayfs
the config file is going to specify what the (administrator) that installed Singularity allows users to do
